title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.13.41 | 18-10-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and invocations.

segments.key_quote: O pious king, do not lament for anyone, for everyone is under the control of the Supreme Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam (1.13.41) and explains its basic meaning: Narada Muni consoles Yudhishthira by stating that everyone is under the control of the Supreme Lord.

segments.key_quote: Every living being either in this material world or in the spiritual world is under the control of the Supreme Lord, the Personality of Godhead.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the concept of Krishna's supreme control, explaining that all beings, from Brahma to the smallest creature, are subject to His order.

segments.key_quote: It is only the devotees and the pious people, the followers of the Vedic injunctions or the scriptural directions given by God, only they are actually voluntarily following the order of the Supreme Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker distinguishes between voluntary obedience by devotees and forced obedience by others, emphasizing the subordinate position of all beings to the Supreme Lord.

segments.key_quote: The foolish living being, especially man artificially rebels against the law of the supreme God...and thus becomes chastised as an asura or law breaker
segments.summary: The speaker explains that rebelling against God's law leads to suffering and punishment, comparing it to breaking earthly laws and facing consequences.

segments.key_quote: A living being is placed in a particular position by the order of the supreme lord and is again shifted from that place by the order of the supreme lord or his authorized agents
segments.summary: The speaker addresses the question of how divine control manifests in practical experience, explaining that beings are placed in and removed from positions by the Lord or His agents, and provides examples of powerful figures throughout history who were ultimately under divine control.

segments.key_quote: Only Krishna is supremely independent...it is only the rebellious souls who suffer
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes Krishna's complete independence and reiterates that suffering is a consequence of rebelling against the Supreme Lord's authority.

segments.key_quote: Whenever he suffers right from the time he is placed in the womb of a particular mother inside the womb he has suffered so much and he forgets that
segments.summary: The speaker illustrates the pervasive nature of suffering, even from infancy, using the analogy of a baby suffering from an ant bite to show how past karma manifests.

segments.key_quote: Intelligent people simply understand that we have to surrender to Krishna the supreme lord and we have to abide by his laws orders and pray to him to get out of this entanglement of material existence
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing the importance of surrendering to Krishna as the only way to overcome the laws of material nature and escape suffering, referencing a verse from the Bhagavad-gita about the difficulty of transcending Maya without surrender.
